i feed her 1 can per day. just split up into 3 different meals. 

it not good for them to graz through out the day like that. they need small 
meals through out the day.
comments.author: popupanimash

comments.text:
+popupanimash Cats are not build to eat few meals a day. They are build to 
eat small amounts ( like a mouse) at once. My cats can eat whenever they 
want. If they get fat, I will make them move more or I get a low fat/low 
calorie food. Depends why they eat more.

my cat goes on her back whenever she wants attention an I tickle her she

top_comment.text:
My 9 year old ginger cat will not drink water unless it was just poured 
into his bowl seconds before he starts drinking. When we flush the toilet, 
he goes straight for it so we have to remember to keep the lid down so he 
doesn't drink our crap water. Disgusting! He will also meow at us 
repeatedly until we serve him water, even if we just did 5 minutes ago. He 
used to have one of those kitty fountains but he would never drink from it 
so we put it away and came back to regular water dishes. There are 3 cats 
in my home and 3 water dishes in different places, still, he is never 
satisfied with the water available to him. #teamcatmojo  ﻿
top_comment.author: PlatypusGuitar

comments.text:
I've heard of this problem before and can explain what is going on with 
your cat, well typically there is nothing wrong with your cat per say, most 
cats just know that fhe freshest water is always the best, call him a 
connoseur if you will because fresh water is just oxygenated and oxygenated 
water is always tasty and fresh than water that the oxygen has already 
evaporated off by sitting for five minutes or so that water does not taste 
as good, so instinctively the cats go for the freshest water they can get 
with more oxygen, oxygen is good for the body, you see cats are no dummies, 
don't you like the water that first comes out of the tap, well see so do 
they, hope I have helped you some, I also was wondering about this type of 
behavior and read about it so I am passing it on to you and this article I 
read sounded quite obvious so I have always remembered that throughout the 
years I have owned cats
comments.author: mshonnie2u

comments.text:
+greenjelly01
oddly enough, that cat is not attracted to wet food. He is not skinny but 
unlike my 2 other cats who throw their faces in their bowls before im even

put him in front of the bowl. And then he lightly nibbles when im not 
looking.
comments.author: PlatypusGuitar

comments.text:
+Wulfgeist
he did have a fountain for a while and never drank from it
comments.author: PlatypusGuitar

comments.text:
I thought that about my cat too, but I discovered that my cat was drinking 
anyway, when I was not watching. Anyway, it is a good idea to give lots of 
wet food, and mix in a few spoons of water with the wet food to keep your 
cat hydrated.
comments.author: greenjelly01

comments.text:
Have you tried getting him a fountain? I've found that cats are crazy for 
running water, they don't much like stagnant bowls sitting around exept 
maybe to play with lol. Honestly, try a pet fountain that recirculates the 
water.

I have a Bengal that is incredibly smart and he figured out how to open

top_comment.text:
My oldest cat does some rather randomly funny Things. He licks the shower 
curtain, and it's not because it's wet. He also like to stick a paw in his 
Water bowl, splash around a Little, then stick it in his food bowl. I have 
absolutely no idea why he's doing this, so any comments would be great :o)﻿
top_comment.author: BlueNoodle79

comments.text:
+Amanda Driggers
Thanks a lot, you've confirmed my suspicions :o)
comments.author: BlueNoodle79

comments.text:
Sometimes cats lick things that are cold, thinking it;s going to quench 
their thirst. I've learned that from raising cats, so when they start doing 
that, I know they are either out of or low on water. As for the splashing 
in the water bowl, she may just be "testing the waters out" or playing in 
it. I have no idea why she sticks it in her food bowl. Maybe she's 
tenderizing it lol :)
comments.author: Amanda Driggers

top_comment.text:
2 yr old Charles, aka Ch Char, is the sweetest boy ever. no exaggeration. 
when he was 1.5 yrs old he started staring at the ceiling and howling. no 
rodents. then he started running in circles and doing that skin rolling 
thing. he didn't stop for hours. the next day we went to the vet, and after 
months of trial and error we have him on phenobarbital for "feline 
hyperesthesia syndrome". now he plays and purrs again and is just the 
sweetest boy around!! Any thoughts on this? it was crazy awful to watch or 
I wouldn't have medically treated him. he's got an old﻿
top_comment.author: Erin Christine

comments.text: My cat sort of does that as well and does it a lot in the basement.
comments.author: Lauren Whipkey

comments.text:
I forgot to mention that my sweet prince Charles plays fetch! He will chase

top_comment.text:
My cat Crowley is almost 2, and he likes to jump on the desk and knock

deliberately push thing off the desk.)﻿
top_comment.author: Espi Kvlt

comments.text:
+muskndusk Have you tried to spray your cat with water when misbehaving? Or 
making a very loud non-human noise like blowing a whistle, clapping your 
hands…  Also, strong lavender smell I use as a repulsive where my cat tries 
to claw that he should not (walls), or where he climbs that is forbidden 
(desk chair. seriously, whenever he sneaks into that chair, he becomes a 
dragon protecting its gold xD )
comments.author: MollyStork

comments.text:
My Violet is a Crowley...she LOVES TO KNOCK everything in her path crashing 
down And watch each item fall,then its on to the next item...I love playing 
with her and sometimes set individually wrapped peppermints,place them all 
on the edge of my bed about 20 of them,and she takes her paw, and baps them 
onto the floor... i love to watch her e, itedly hit them down ...
I love it too!
comments.author: Diane Nageeb

comments.text: +Espi Kvlt AWESOME!!
comments.author: Playfulpanthress

comments.text:
+muskndusk What you're saying goes against anything I"ve been told by every 
professional.
comments.author: Espi Kvlt

comments.text:
+Espi Kvlt
No, just addressing the notion that ignoring bad behaviour will prevent it 
happening in the future. This is predicated on the idea that a pet is 
seeking attention in the first place. Most cats, like yours, aren't 
actually doing this - they get enough positive attention anyway. If a pet 
misbehaves in order to get attention, the cure is to give him/her MORE 
attention, not less, but at appropriate times. Your cat gets lots of love 
and fuss, I imagine, so is toying with items on your desk to amuse himself, 
not to gain your attention. Ignoring him just gives him space to continue 
the unwanted behaviour; he couldn't care less whether you give him 
attention; but a sharp no will tell him that the desk isn't his playground.
comments.author: muskndusk

comments.text:
+muskndusk You're implying I don't praise my cats when they do something 
good...
comments.author: Espi Kvlt

comments.text:
+Espi Kvlt
I'm aware of the 'ignore' behaviour modification technique, but don't 100% 
agree with it. Would you ignore a cat who was, as one of mine used to do, 
sticking her paw into the gas fire. Yes, this really happened, often, and 
my instinct was to shout a sharp no to make her remove her paw before it 
got burned. She liked the warmth (that house was a cold one, unlike my 
current house).
Likewise, I wouldn't ignore a cat who was disorganising important papers on 
my desk. My cats are given lots of attention when they are good - positive 
attention which they enjoy, rather than the negative response (which they 
hate) when they do something unwanted.
Look up Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Behaviour Modification and you'll 
find that the ignore method is one of the least effective for changing 
behaviour. The best is positive reinforcement of good behaviour.
comments.author: muskndusk

comments.text:
+muskndusk That's giving them attention. As far as I've learned from every 
cat behaviorist, any sort of attention is the wrong reaction. (There's no 
laptop on the desk.)
comments.author: Espi Kvlt

comments.text: +Playfulpanthress Yep! Ha ha. The other's name is Castiel.
comments.author: Espi Kvlt

comments.text:
You do nothing while your cat is knocking everything off your desk? Even 
the laptop?
Just say a sharp "No!" and "Down!" while pointing to the floor. Then ignore 
him.
comments.author: muskndusk

comments.text:
I LOVE your cat's name!! Was he by chance named after the beloved king of 
hell?
comments.author: Playfulpanthress

comments.text:
+Marieke De Jong
Would it be financially possible for you to move somewhere with a safe 
garden for her to play in? This would be the ideal situation as she doesn't 
sound like an ideal indoor only cat. Perhaps providing play trees, there 
are many on the market, for her might give her something to run on and 
release that energy.

comments.text:
+muskndusk Thanks for your reaction!
I live in a appartment with no garden. So I also only have one cat because 
of the space. The only outside space I have is a balcony.
She can go there when im with her, because she will jump on the railing and 
that scares me alot!
I do have extra chickenfencing on the rails.
At the moment im sick at home, so i've not worked since Januari. But 
normaly I work from 8.30-12.00 and 14.30 - 18.30 so im at home alot you 
would say.
I do play with her, but not 24/7 ofcourse.
During the day she seems fine and is very friendly, playfull and talks 
alot. But during the night its seems she gets frustrated over something.
comments.author: Marieke De Jong

comments.text:
She sounds frustrated. Is she an indoor cat with limited play space? Would 
it be possible to cat-proof your garden or construct an outdoor run if you 
can't allow her out? Is she an only cat? Are you at work alot? I sense that 
she's bored and has lots of pent up energy.
comments.author: muskndusk

top_comment.text:
Hey Jackson, I'm confused about my cat's behavior. Her name is Miley and 
she's 7 years old. 
Well, she's very sociable with people, but you'll see, I have two more cats 
in the house, I got them a few years ago, but, for example, I'm with 
another cat and we are relax, then Miley gets closer, all cool, and sudenly 
Miley atacks the other cat. The other cat does nothing and stay calm, and 
Miley runs away, like she didn't knows the other cat. Sometimes this 
happens after she licks or rubs the other cat. Makes me think she's 
bipolar. Why does Miley do that?
P.S.: Miley can easly share the same place with both (food place, sleep 
place). She only atacks when she interacts directly with them. ﻿
top_comment.author: Mariana Isabel Zepeda

comments.text:
Oh thanks so much Aria! This is very helpful, And probably you're very 
right, I'll try to play more with Miley. You're such an angel. Happy 
Hollidays to you!
comments.author: Mariana Isabel Zepeda

comments.text:
this is a very good issue, and one that many people don't understand, lovey 
one minute and then boom, attack, but, its not an attack, if it was, the 
other cat would feel threatened, and react, good or bad, but like u said, 
the cat does it, runs and the cat "attacked" does nothing, its quiet 
simple, Miley is playing, cats will always build up energy, old and new, 
playing helps release that energy, so miley is simply stating, I want to 
play, the other cat does nothing, and doesn't react to it, is cuz that cat 
simply doesn't want to play, miley will go on, and play with something 
else, on another note, cat's are pretators, they hunt, playing helps them 
keep their hunting skills in top notch, this is also a reason cats play 
"All the time", Miley, on top of being a playfull kitty, is trying to stay 
in a very good hunting condition, my suggestion for u, play with ur cats 
more, idk how much u play with ur cats, but to Miley, its not enough, she 
still rearing to go, play more, the more u play till miley walks away, the 
better, eventually u will c a different miley, a less "Attacking" miley. 
P.S: never persue a cat, when they walk away, that's them saying "im done" 
or "im gonna go do something else"
comments.author: Aria Ferranew

comments.text:
+muskndusk
That is so true.  However, my vet also said that some dry cat foods use a 
red dye that can cause an allergic reaction in some cats.  My cats had the 
same situation, licking and biting themselves until they had no fur near 
the base of the tail.  When I changed my dry food to one that had no red 
dyes in it, they stopped and their fur grew back to make them the beautiful 
cats they are.

comments.author: Amanda Driggers

top_comment.text:
My cat has only lived here for a couple months, so I consider any change in 
her behavior to be her warming up, getting more comfortable, and/or 
settling in. But a couple weeks ago, she stopped eating dry food. Just out 
of the blue, one morning, no more dry food. She was obviously hungry; when 
I put down food and treats for her she would hover over them and sniff and 
pace and put her face in them, and her tail would be up and she would purr. 
With the treats, she'd even put them in her mouth, crack them open, and 
then put them back on the floor. She hovered around her food constantly, 
just pacing and staring at the bowl. After a few days, she actually went so 
far as tearing open the dry food bag. I gave her a different brand, I tried 
different treats. But she won't eat anything she has to chew.

Except, here's the bizarre part. She tears paper up with her teeth (but 
doesn't eat it, just shreds it). She chews on my fingers when we play. She 
chews on toys. She chews on her claws when she's grooming to get stuff out 
of them. She loves to cuddle and play, and she loves guests. When my 
brother had his wedding a couple weeks ago, she was more social than I was!

When I took her to the vet, she said her teeth look fine and it sounded 
like she just had gotten bored. There could be an imperceptible crack, but 
to find that, they'd have to put her under anesthesia, and that makes me 
nervous, as I know multiple dogs and cats who died while getting their 
teeth cleaned.

After a week of hoping she was just bored of her food, and after .7 pounds 
of weight loss (she's only an 8 lb cat), I put her on a wet food diet. 
She'll eat that with no problem. But I know that wet food this early in her 
life can lead to teeth problems down the road, and I want to get this 
figured out and get her back on dry food. But I know there has to be an 
underlying problem that I just haven't spotted, and the fact that I can't 
figure out what's making her uncomfortable makes me frustrated and feel a 
little helpless. You've taught me well, Jackson; nothing is ever truly 
random!

Additional information: during the couple months I've had her, my cat has 
had a sinus infection and an ear infection (no mites; just an infection). 
She was a feral stray until last November and had kittens when she was 8 
months old. She has no litterbox problems. She's harness-trained and likes 
to go out on the porch with me, but is not allowed to free-roam outdoors 
(and I don't think she'd want to if she could). She plays about 3 hours a 
day and likes to always be in the same room as me. Before she stopped 
eating dry food on me, the last wet food she'd had was at the shelter. I 
gave her Purina One; now I give her Publix brand, because it's the only 
food that's sustainable financially but not suspiciously cheap. When she 
ate dry food, she threw up every couple days until I switched her to 
sensitive stomach food.﻿
top_comment.author: Lex McLlellan

comments.text:
Some cats become finicky especially when the food has suddenly been changed 
so if you have changed the brand or variety this is why your cat suddenly 
stopped eating it, or the location is too busy and there could be a foul 
odor or that spot was territorially marked by another animal and this is 
why your cat could not be eating, try moving the food to a different spot 
each day until you find just the right eating spot, I've done this with my 
pets and it has worked
comments.author: mshonnie2u

comments.text:
Wet food is way better than dry. It's not proven that dry food is good for 
teeth. Google why dry cat food is bad and why wet food is better
comments.author: Valentina Federico

top_comment.text:
while im commenting here can anyone please help me to stop my cat wrecking 
my carpet. Hes clawed at it everyday for 5 years, there are scratch posts 
all over the house that I put catnip on and he sometimes uses. Ive got mats 
and towels all over the floor and stairs, ive tried pet repellent, ive 
tried telling him 'no', ive tried clipping his claws, ive tried everything! 
he is actually driving me crazy but apart from this hes really happy and 
relaxed.﻿
top_comment.author: karenKristal

comments.text:
Buy an empty squirt bottle (I got mine at the dollar store) fill it with 
water, & squirt him when he's in the process. Usually works, unless you own 
a water loving cat.
comments.author: Amanda Driggers

comments.text: He seems to prefer horizontal scratching rather than vertical
comments.author: Melissa Vargas Jerez

comments.text:
+Melissa Greenberg hi I don't really know what he does when im out (as the 
carpet is already damaged) but I know he does it when Im asleep cos the 
noise wakes me up, and sometimes when Im downstairs I can hear him 
scratching at the stair carpet. But then when I put one of the scratch 
posts in front of him and tell him to use it he does. I think Ive confused 
him by telling him not to scratch and then to scratch. I think he just does 
it because he likes to. My other cat only ever scratches the posts.
comments.author: karenKristal

comments.text:
You should also get multiple scratching items.  So maybe one of those that 
they can lay in, a regular post, and try to get scratchers with more than 
one type of material on them.  If they don't like one material, they may 
like the other.

Also, I know my cat only scratches on inappropriate items (like the doors, 
couches, bed) when she wants something.  She always does it when I'm around 
and only when I am from what I can tell.  So are you always around when she 
does this?  Or always away?  Is there always a certain person in the room? 
 Another pet?  She may be communicating with you.
comments.author: Melissa Greenberg

comments.text: np, always happy to help people as much as I can
comments.author: Aria Ferranew

comments.text: thanks Ill definitely try that
comments.author: karenKristal

comments.text:
cats wont recognize "no" as a language, its not in their vocabulary, but, 
like Michelle above said, its the texture, cats like to have something to 
scratch, its a way for them to keep there body's in check, preferably, 
their claws, now with carpet's being in many different variaties, cats will 
turn to the carpet, cuz they like the feel of it, so, try this, ur cat 
loves scratching the carpet, so get something, anything, wood, a log, a cat 
climber, something, and cover it with the same brand and type of carpet u 
have, I assure u ur cat will most likely b scratching that, then the carpet 
on ur floor, it could also very well b territorial, as cats are extremely 
territorial, marking it as their area, so again, with that post with the 
carpet, will give em a place to call their own
comments.author: Aria Ferranew

comments.text:
thanks, I guess my carpet is normal (for a home, it would be quite fluffy 
for a public area) I actually think hes getting a bit better but my carpets 
wrecked anyway now :-/
comments.author: karenKristal

comments.text:
What Laura Brouwer said. Some cats will just claw a certain kind of thing 
and nothing else. It's cat logic - buy a scratching post but instead they 
like the carpet instead. My cats still claw the carpet now but a while back 
they were doing it even more. Is your carpet the thick kind or thin? (I'm 
not sure on the terminology) The thicker one will get scratched more. 
Basically, you remove what they're fixated on and it'll be better. Maybe 
don't always let him inside - and therefore cutting down his access to the 
carpet. My cats were running rampant at night time - ruining furniture in 
every way possible - and I ended up (mostly as a deterrent or "punishment") 
lock them up in the laundry (where the litter is, and obviously well 
ventilated, etc) overnight. Even though they are cats, they WILL act like 
children and therefore need deterring.
comments.author: Michelle Pahlke

comments.text:
Your cat isn't that happy as you think he is. He's probably really bored 
and when cats get bored they're starting to wreck things. Play with him at 
least a quarter a day. Keep him busy, give your cat opportunities to play 
and hunt and give him a lot of attention!
comments.author: Laura Brouwer

comments.text: Send the carpet to a vacation :)
comments.author: Ashlee Candazo

captions.text:
Why does your cat
climb the curtains?

Why does your cat
scratch at the couch?

Why is my cat trying
to make me crazy?

If you are asking that question,
this episode of Cat Mojo
is for you, people.

Are you set to take a deeper,
deeper look at catification?
Let's go.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
OK.

So today, we're going to
talk about solving problems,

but solving problems in
a way that you might not
have thought before.

We have already talked
about the 360 mojo, people--

the big mojo up
there and your cat.

But this is the
next step-- cat mojo
102-- being a cat journalist.

I just got a picture in my
head of a cat with a fedora on,

and licking the pencil,
and like, come on,
now-- give me an exclusive.
I really need this scoop.

I mean, my job is
depending on it, Charlie.

That's not what
we're dealing with.

We're dealing with you
being a journalist-- writing

a journal-- writing a
story like a journalist.

So to be a cat journalist, the
first thing-- the biggest thing

in the picture, here,
is a little dose-- just

a teeny little dose
of objectivity.

If you are using language
like, my cat hates me;
my cat hates my boyfriend.

If you make it about your
relationship with your cat,

you're already too deep
into this whole thing.

Get a little bit of objectivity
about what's going on here.

But look at this story from
the perspective of somebody

that you have empathy
toward, right?

You can't cast your
cat as a villain
and expect to get anywhere.
No behaviors are random.

If you're saying, my cat
randomly attacks me-- no.

If we're not dealing with
a bad tooth or a tumor

or a chemical imbalance,
the rest of it

comes from here, within
these four walls.

So to be a cat
journalist, you have

to pretend you don't
live in those four walls.

Say your cat did
something randomly.

You have to take a look at that
day, and really take it apart.
Anything out of the ordinary?

Anything energetically
in the house

that may have just come
to a head that day?

Let's do that with the
what's, the wheres,

and the hows of your
cat's couple of days,

couple of minutes,
couple of hours,

from the moment that something
went really bad in your house.
What threatened the territory?

Now, another point in cat
journalism is patience.

Being a cat journalist is like
being a cop on a stakeout.

You're going to sit
there and you're

going to eat a lot of doughnuts
and drink a lot of coffee

and watch a whole lot of nothing
until something shows you
what you need.

So many of us would go to
this place of first, defiance,

anger-- why are you
doing this to me?

Now you put on your
cat journalist fedora.
What's going on in your world?
Tell me all about it.
I'm all ears.

Now, of course you're
going to go to the vet.
Of course.
That's part of journalism.
OK.
Well, clean bill of health.
Nothing going on.
No pain.
No discomfort.

What I want you guys to
do-- homework, please.
Pow.

Tell me what is the most random
thing your cat has ever done.

Write me something
right down here,

or write it on
Twitter or Facebook.

Just #TeamCatMojo
and I will see it.

And make sure that you
include how old they

were, what their names
are-- the basics.

I want to see a
whole bunch of these.

And then together-- I'm
going to take a few of these.

We're going to go through
some of the story lines,

and we are going
to work this out.

I'm going to pick three--
count them-- three

of the most random
cat things that
have ever happened in your home.

And I'm going to give away some
serious prizes on this one.

Folks, the party
is just starting.

If you go to Twitter, or
Instagram, Facebook, Google+,
YouTube-- we are everywhere.
Team Cat Mojo in full effect.

All you get to do
is #TeamCatMojo

and I will see what
you're talking about,
and so will the rest of us.
And keep it coming, man.
Subscribe to this here channel.

Let me know what you want
to see during Cat Mojo,

because that's how
these episodes are born.

And don't forget, My Cat From
Hell, season five premiering
just in what, a month or so?
We're going to have some fun.
All right, folks.
That's it for me.
Hey, listen.
Be good to each other.

Be good to the
animals in your life.

And hey, be good to the animals
that are not even in your life.

You'll feel good about
it, and hey, that's
what Team Cat Mojo is all about.

Until next time, all light,
all love, and all mojo to you.
THEME SONG: You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.
[ANIMAL NOISES]

title: Find Out Why Your Cat is Being Crazy!
